title: Fact Check: Pregnant women are not more susceptible to COVID-19.
text:
Claim: Pregnant women are not more susceptible to COVID-19.

Verdict: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking

Justification: QA Pairs state that:

pregnant women with COVID-19 do not appear to be at increased risk 

While another says:
Pregnant women or recently pregnant women who are  older, overweight, and have pre-existing medical conditions such as hypertension and diabetes seem to have an increased  risk of developing severe COVID-19
Due to changes in their bodies and immune systems, we know that pregnant women can be badly affected by some respiratory infections. It is therefore important that they take precautions to protect themselves against COVID-19, and report possible symptoms (including fever, cough or difficulty in breathing) to their healthcare provider.

So other health factors seem to play a part.



Evidence:

Q: What is this claim based on?
A: Caring for Women Who Are Planning a Pregnancy, Pregnant, or Postpartum During the COVID-19 Pandemic. 

Q: What does the JAMA article say about pregnant women & Covid-19?
A: Since its recognition in China in December 2019, coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has rapidly spread throughout the world and become a pandemic. Although considerable data on COVID-19 are available, much remains to be learned about its effects on pregnant women and newborns.

No data are currently available to assess whether pregnant women are more susceptible to COVID-19. Pregnant women are at risk for severe disease associated with other respiratory illnesses (eg, 2009 H1N1 influenza),1 but thus far, pregnant women with COVID-19 do not appear to be at increased risk for severe disease compared with the general population. 

Q: What do the WHO guidelines say about the risks of Covid-19 for pregnant women?
A: Pregnant women or recently pregnant women who are  older, overweight, and have pre-existing medical conditions such as hypertension and diabetes seem to have an increased  risk of developing severe COVID-19
Due to changes in their bodies and immune systems, we know that pregnant women can be badly affected by some respiratory infections. It is therefore important that they take precautions to protect themselves against COVID-19, and report possible symptoms (including fever, cough or difficulty in breathing) to their healthcare provider..

title: Fact Check: Viral message claims Facebook will make private photos public
text:
Claim: Viral message claims Facebook will make private photos public

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: According to Facebook, If you share a photo on Facebook you automatically grant permission to store, copy, and share it with others (again, consistent with your settings). Facebook will not make private photos public. 

Evidence:

Q: Can Facebook make your photos go public?
A: If you share a photo on Facebook, you give us permission to store, copy, and share it with others (again, consistent with your settings) such as service providers that support our service or other Facebook Products you use. This license will end when your content is deleted from our systems.”. 

Q: Will posting in the post in the claim change Facebooks policies?
A: This means if we deactivate our account, Facebook will delete the stored data from our profile. Apart from that, the author, i.e. the one who posts the article, owns the copyright of the content.
We don’t sell your personal data to advertisers, and we don’t share information that directly identifies you (such as your name, email address, or other contact information) with advertisers unless you give us specific permission.
So posting the viral message on your wall will not change Facebook’s policies.. 

Q: Will posting a viral message on your Facebook wall change Facebook permissions?
A: No. Posting a viral message will not make facebook change the privacy settings on your account..

title: Fact Check: People with no recourse to public funds are not yet able to claim free school me...
text:
Claim: People with no recourse to public funds are not yet able to claim free school meal vouchers in the UK

Verdict: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking

Justification: Some can claim free school meals, and some can't. 

Evidence:

Q: What does "no recourse to public funds" mean?
A: No recourse to public funds (NRPF) is a standard condition applied to those staying here with a temporary immigration status to protect public funds. Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) is set as the general threshold for permitting migrants to access public funds. Migrants who are here without leave are also subject to no recourse to public funds. Therefore, most migrants do not have access to public funds as a matter of course.. 

Q: During the pandemic do children from NRPF groups have access to free school meals?
A: Some of them do:-
During the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, we are temporarily extending free school meal eligibility to include some children of groups who have no recourse to public funds (NRPF).

These groups are:

children of Zambrano carers
children of families with no recourse to public funds with a right to remain in the UK on grounds of private and family life under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights
children of families receiving support under Section 17 of the Children Act 1989 who are also subject to a no recourse to public funds restriction.

title: Fact Check: The low-cost steroid dexamethasone is a “life-saving” drug for COVID-19 patients...
text:
Claim: The low-cost steroid dexamethasone is a “life-saving” drug for COVID-19 patients.

Verdict: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking

Justification: Confirmed as a low cost drug.

Effectively reduced deaths in 1/3 of people on ventilators.

Effectively reduced deaths by 20% in those on oxygen.

No Benefit among patients not receiving respiratory support.

I have marked conflicting evidence because it saves some people in some circumstances.

Not effective in those 



Evidence:

Q: What research has been conducted into the effectiveness of dexamethosone as a COVID-19 treatment?
A: The British Government clinical trial tested six treatment options as part of its RECOVERY trial. One of these was dexamethosone.. 

Q: What did the government's RECOVERY trial find out about the effectiveness of dexamethosone as a COVID-19 treatment?
A: Dexamethasone reduced deaths by one-third in ventilated patients (rate ratio 0.65 [95% confidence interval 0.48 to 0.88]; p=0.0003) and by one fifth in other patients receiving oxygen only (0.80 [0.67 to 0.96]; p=0.0021). There was no benefit among those patients who did not require respiratory support (1.22 [0.86 to 1.75]; p=0.14).

Based on these results, 1 death would be prevented by treatment of around 8 ventilated patients or around 25 patients requiring oxygen alone.. 

Q: What have medical professionals said about the use of dexamethasone against the coronavirus?
A: Department of Health on Wednesday advised the public to be cautious in interpreting the preliminary study findings that steroid drug dexamethasone can reduce the risk of the sickest patients dying from coronavirus disease.

DOH expressed concern that this discovery might lead people to ‘think it is a magic pill for COVID-19.’.

title: Fact Check: Donald Trump made Juneteenth "very famous," as he described in a Wall Street Jou...
text:
Claim: Donald Trump made Juneteenth "very famous," as he described in a Wall Street Journal interview June 17, 2020. Prior to him planning a rally on June 19, "nobody had ever heard of it."

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: it's clear from the answers that Juneteenth had been famous for a very long time, prior to Donald Trump

Evidence:

Q: What is Jointh?
A: The tradition started in 1866 in Texas and spread to nearby states.

The Civil Rights movement infused Juneteenth with new energy.

Today, 47 states recognize the day.. 

Q: What is Juneteenth?
A: The tradition started in 1866 in Texas and spread to nearby states.

The Civil Rights movement infused Juneteenth with new energy.

Today, 47 states recognize the day.. 

Q: Where does Juneteenth stem from?
A: Juneteenth is the oldest known celebration of African American freedom, marking the ending of slavery in the U.S. 
It commemorates the week in June 1865 that Major Gen. Gordon Granger led the Union soldiers to Galveston, Texas, declaring the war was over and the enslaved could go free. 
While President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation officially freed slaves more than two years earlier, it was the surrender of General Lee in April 1865 and Granger’s arrival with the troops that created a force strong enough to overcome Texas’ resistance to the executive order to free slaves. 
The culmination of Granger’s trip led to his June 19 reading of the proclamation, coined as “Juneteenth” — the day the freed slaves and their families recounted memories, reassured each other of a newly-promised future and gathered in prayer..

title: Fact Check: Establishing A One World Government is Part Of UN's 'mission goals.
text:
Claim: Establishing A One World Government is Part Of UN's 'mission goals.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The source which is the UN official website does not mention the specific goal mentioned in the claim and therefore the claim is refuted.

Evidence:

Q: What are the UN mission goals
A: Goal 1. End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
Goal 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
Goal 4. Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
Goal 5. Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
Goal 6. Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
Goal 7. Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all
Goal 8. Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
Goal 9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation
Goal 10. Reduce inequality within and among countries
Goal 11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
Goal 12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns
Goal 13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts*
Goal 14. Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development
Goal 15. Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, and halt and reverse land degradation and halt biodiversity loss
Goal 16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
Goal 17. Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development.

title: Fact Check: A study conducted by World Health Organization (WHO) and major hospitals has fou...
text:
Claim: A study conducted by World Health Organization (WHO) and major hospitals has found that Covid-19 has become weaker and harmless.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Evidence provided of WHO stating it does not believe Covid-19 has become less pathogenic.

Evidence:

Q: What is the World Health Organisation?
A: The World Health Organisation (WHO) is a specialised agency of the United Nations, established in 1948. The constitution of WHO was signed by 61 countries in 1946, which has increased to a total of 164 countries in 2016.. 

Q: Has anyone indicated that Covid-19 has become weaker and less lethal at any point?
A: Yes. An Italian doctor Alberto Zangrillo has suggested that it has become weaker and practically no longer exists in Italy.

Q: Has WHO responded to claims by the Italian doctor?
A: Yes. They have responded directly regarding the Italian doctors claims in a press conference video and clarified that they do not believe it is less potent or significantly weaker by stating, 

"We need to be exceptionally careful not to create a sense that, all of a sudden, the virus, by its own volition, has now decided to be less pathogenic. It is not the case at all," WHO emergencies director Michael Ryan tells a virtual press briefing.

title: Fact Check: Herbal medicine from Tanzania cure Covid-19
text:
Claim: Herbal medicine from Tanzania cure Covid-19

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The answer and sources show that the claim is fake news so the claim is refuted.

Evidence:

Q: When was this claim made?
A: 2020. 

Q: Does the claim say the cure is backed by the government of Tanzania?
A: Yes. Claim states the cure was brought out by the government.

Q: Has the Tanzanian government confirmed this Covid cure?
A: On May 3, the Tanzanian health ministry issued a statement clarifying that no medicine to cure Covid-19 is available as of now..

title: Fact Check: Former President Barack Obama was born in Kenya, according to his birth certific...
text:
Claim: Former President Barack Obama was born in Kenya, according to his birth certificate.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Obama's birth certificate has been confirmed as authentic by a Hawaii Department of Health official, thus confirming he was born in Hawaii, and not Kenya.

Evidence:

Q: Where was former President Barack Obama born, according to his birth certificate?
A: Barack Hussein Obama II was born in Honolulu, Hawaii, United States. 

Q: Has the Hawaii Department of Health verified the authenticity of Barack Obama's birth certificate?
A: Yes. A Hawaii Department of Health official, Loretta Fuddy, confirmed Obama's "long form" birth certificate as part of the state's effort to put to rest questions about whether he was really born in the United States.

title: Fact Check: Denis Mukwege, a medical doctor and Nobel Peace laureate from the Democratic Rep...

In a resignation note publicised on Wednesday, Dr Mukwege said the lack of laboratories for testing for the virus had frustrated the team’s work..

title: Fact Check: An Expansion of Mail-in Ballots would increase the chance of theft in the USA.
text:
Claim: An Expansion of Mail-in Ballots would increase the chance of theft in the USA.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The QA cover a lot of ground in terms of information around voter fraud and mail in ballots, there good probing question and good answers which give a very good view of it and allow for a good decision on the claim. Based on the information gathered from the QA it appears the claim itself was made by Donald Trump, we know that he has a problem with mail in ballots as he often refers to them as being a method of rigging an election, the QA has found that Donald Trump himself however used a mail in absentee ballot to vote. Theres plenty of information from further QA to discover that theres lots of secure safeguards in place to both prevent voter fraud and it also prooves that someone is not possible to vote by mail then in person. For this claim I have therefore refuted it.

Evidence:

Q: Who made this claim about the potential for theft of mail in ballots?
A: Donald Trump. 

Q: Has Donald Trump voted by mail in ballot?
A: Trump voted earlier this year, in a no-excuse absentee vote state -- meaning that a voter can request an absentee ballot (aka one you fill out at home and mail back to the election authority) without offering any excuse for why they want to do so.
Which is what Trump did. Being president is a more than full-time job, and he couldn't make time to travel to Florida to cast a vote in person. So he voted absentee.. 

Q: How secure is mail in voting (absentee ballot voteing)?
A: Numerous safeguards are included in the absentee voting process. Absentee ballots are sent only to registered voters who request them using an official N.C. Absentee Ballot Request Form before the deadline. The request must be signed and include identifying information about the voter, including date of birth and driver’s license number or last four digits of the voter’s Social Security number. Voters must vote their ballot in the presence of two witnesses or a notary, and those witnesses must sign the absentee return envelope certifying that the voter marked their ballot and is the registered voter submitting the marked ballot.

Only the voter or their near relative or legal guardian may return the ballot. Upon return, the county board of elections reviews the absentee envelope to ensure compliance with the legal requirements. Once the ballot is accepted, that voter is marked in the system as having voted in that election.

Data on who has requested absentee ballots is now confidential until Election Day. Criminal penalties have been increased for absentee voting fraud-related offenses. Many people are watching our absentee voting process, including candidates, political parties, county boards of elections, and political and data scientists. If there are anomalies or questionable activities, they will be identified by or reported to election officials.

Finally, the State Board of Elections has an Investigations Division that investigates credible allegations of elections fraud and refers cases to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence. The State Board also conducts several post-election audits which will catch inconsistencies that can then be investigated by the board or the Investigations Division..

title: Fact Check: Absentee voters in the USA have to go through a Very strict process.
text:
Claim: Absentee voters in the USA have to go through a Very strict process.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Each state has their own process for voting  therefore the claim is ref5

Evidence:

Q: What are permissible reasons for absentee voting
A: a voter must be able to personally mark their own ballot and sign their name to the completed ballot security envelope and have a reason to request an absentee vote-by-mail ballot:

You have a specific, reasonable expectation that you will be absent from the county on Election Day during the entire 12 hours that the polls are open (6 am until 6 pm).
You have a disability.
You are at least 65 years of age.
You will have official election duties outside of your voting precinct.
You are scheduled to work at your regular place of employment during the entire 12 hours that the polls are open.
You will be confined due to illness or injury or you will be caring for an individual confined due to illness or injury during the entire 12 hours that the polls are open.
You are prevented from voting because of a religious discipline or religious holiday during the entire 12 hours that the polls are open.
You are a participant in the state's address confidentiality program.
You are a member of the military or a public safety officer.
You are a "serious sex offender" as defined in Indiana Code 35-42-4-14(a).
You are prevented from voting due to the unavailability of transportation to the polls.. 

Q: Are there other processes involved in absentee voting asides the States recognized laws
A: No. Each state in the US has its own rules as regards absentee voting and where its permitted, the rules and requirements are not so different from each other

title: Fact Check: The Boy Scouts are supporting Black Lives Matter and are required to earn a dive...
text:
Claim: The Boy Scouts are supporting Black Lives Matter and are required to earn a diversity badge.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: the answers confirm the claim.

Evidence:

Q: Are the Boy Scouts actively supporting Black lives matter?
A: Yes. An official statement from the Boy Scouts of America states the following: The Boy Scouts of America stands with Black families and the Black community because we believe that Black Lives Matter. This is not a political issue; it is a human rights issue and one we all have a duty to address.

Q: Do Boy Scouts have to earn a diversity badge?
A: Yes. An official statement from the Boy Scouts of America states the following: Introducing a specific diversity and inclusion merit badge that will be required for the rank of Eagle Scout. It will build on components within existing merit badges, including the American Cultures and Citizenship in the Community merit badges, which require Scouts to learn about and engage with other groups and cultures to increase understanding and spur positive action.

Q: Did Steve Harvey appreciate Donald Trump’s ‘Raccoons’ on Facebook?
A: No answer could be found..

A: No answer could be found..

text:

Aggrieved students to address their concerns to university bodies who shall take judicious call based on the prevailing local situations.

#Students are forwarding grievances related to conduct of semester exams. #AICTE has already endorsed UGC guidelines for its approved institutions. Aggrieved students to address their concerns to university bodies who shall take judicious call based on prevailing local situation.

title: Fact Check: Mexico is leaving the most difficult stage of the COVID-19 pandemic and I consid...
text:

If covid-19 testing is low, the possiblies of knowing how well Mexico is handling the pandemic is unknown due to unreliable numbers. For example, if low covid-19 testing is done then Mexico may report low covid-19 cases, but this may not be a valid statistic as not enough people are getting tested. Therefore, this claim is refuted.

Evidence:

Q: what was Mexico's efforts towards the covid 19 pandemic
A: Mexico was one of the countries that had the lowest level of covid-19 testing [0.4]. 

Q: How many deaths were recorded in Mexico City after the claim was made
A: Between March 18 and May 12, 4,577 death certificates were issued in Mexico City in which the words Covid-19, or coronavirus or Sars Cov 2, appear as the cause of death, confirmed or probable; that is, 3 times more deaths related to the pandemic than those reported by official figures..

title: Fact Check: Milwaukee declared racism as a public health crisis in 2019.
text:

A: Officials signed the ordinance one year after Milwaukee County passes a first-of-kind resolution declaring racism as a public health crisis in May 2019.. 

Q: Why did Milwaukee declare racism as a public health crisis in 2019 ?
A: Milwaukee, both the city and county, passed resolutions last summer that were seen as important steps in addressing decades of race-based inequality.

“We declared racism as a public health issue,” said Kowalik, the city’s health commissioner. “It frames not only how we do our work but how transparent we are about how things are going. It impacts how we manage an outbreak.

title: Fact Check: The Ministry of Home Affairs of India has decided to implement a complete lockdo...
text:
Claim: The Ministry of Home Affairs of India has decided to implement a complete lockdown in Delhi-NCR from June 18, 2020 for four weeks.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Q&A1 establishes that the MHA was introducing unlocking and Q&A2 directly refutes this claim.

Evidence:

Q: What lockdown measures has India announced for June 2020?
A: For the first time since the first lockdown was announced on March 24, the government for the first time moved towards unlocking the country, with easing of several restrictions in non-containment areas. As per the government, like the nationwide lockdown, the unlocking will also be done in three parts. The guidelines issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) on Saturday comprised guidelines for phase 1 of resumption of economic activities across states. These guidelines will come into effect from June 1, 2020, and will be effective till June 30, 2020.. 

Q: Was there a complete lockdown plan in Delhi NCR by the Ministry of Home Affairs, from June 18 onwards for four weeks ?
A: The Press Information Bureau (PIB), in a tweet, clarified that the government has no such plans as of yet. There is no such plan under consideration. Please beware of rumour mongers..

title: Fact Check: Trump said Christians thought his Bible photo op was “beautiful.”
text:
Claim: Trump said Christians thought his Bible photo op was “beautiful.”

Q: Did Donald Trump take a photo of him holding a Bible?
A: Yes. resident Donald Trump held up a Bible during a photo opportunity in front of St. John's Episcopal Church in the midst of ongoing protests over racial inequality

Q: Was Donald Trump Criticized by Christians for his photo of him holding a bible?
A: The Rt. Rev. Mariann Budde, said, “The symbolism of him holding a Bible … as a prop and standing in front of our church as a backdrop when everything that he has said is antithetical to the teachings of our traditions and what we stand for as a church — I was horrified,”. 

Q: Could some Christians have agreed and thought the photo was Beutiful?
A: Yes. Only the Mainstream U.S. Protestant and Catholic leaders criticized President Donald Trump

title: Fact Check: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria says the GDP grew from 1.91% in 2018 to 2....
text:
Claim: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria says the GDP grew from 1.91% in 2018 to 2.27% in 2019 but declined to 1.87% in the first quarter of 2020 as a result of the decline in global economic activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The answers and credible sources show that the percentages are all correct so the claim is supported.

Evidence:

Q: How much was the growth of the GDP in Nigeria between 2018 and 2019?
A: The annual real GDP in 2018 grew by 1.91%, which was more than double the growth rate recorded in 2017 which stood at 0.82%. In the first quarter of 2019, real GDP grew by 2.10% indicating a faster pace of expansion on a quarterly basis. In the second quarter of 2019, Nigeria’s real GDP at basic prices grew by 2.12% on a year on year  basis. Growth accelerated further in the third and fourth quarters by 2.28% and 2.55%. The steady increase in quarterly growth resulted in an annual growth rate of 2.27% for 2019, compared to 1.91% in 2018 on a year on year basis.. 

Q: What was the GDP in Nigeria in the first quarter of 2020?
A: In the first quarter of 2020, Nigeria’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 1.87%(year-on-year) in real terms. This performance was recorded against the backdrop of significant global disruptions resulting from the COVID-19 public health crisis, a sharp fall in oil prices and restricted international trade..

title: Fact Check: Trump said that to a lot of people “defunding the police” means breaking up poli...
text:
Claim: Trump said that to a lot of people “defunding the police” means breaking up police forces or not giving them any money

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: No, it means diverting some of the police's budget into community problems and reduce crime that way.

Evidence:

Q: What do activists mean by "defund the police"
A: to reduce the types of calls that officers respond to and reallocate police funding toward other community services.

Kailee Scales, a leader of the Black Lives Matter movement, said the group was calling for a "divestment in police in order to support more teachers, mental health and restorative services, community resilience departments, social workers, and government resource liaisons.". 

Q: Does this mean breaking up the police force?
A: No. While some do want to eliminate the police departments, most want to reallocate funding

title: Fact Check: Black Lives Matter Scotland have produced posters and stickers with phrases such...
text:
Claim: Black Lives Matter Scotland have produced posters and stickers with phrases such as “Kill a white on sight” on them.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Q&A pair 2 state that a spokesperson for Black lives matter Scotland denied they had made or placed the posters as claimed, and 1st the Q&A pair also does mention the posters content being harefull which supports the claim also.

Evidence:

Q: What is Black Lives Matter?
A: The movement was born in 2013, after the man who shot and killed an unarmed black teenager, Trayvon Martin, was cleared of his murder. A Californian activist, Alicia Garza, responded to the jury’s decision on Facebook with a post that ended: “Black people. I love you. I love us. Our lives matter.” The hashtag was born, and continued to grow in prominence with each new incident and protest.

The formal organization that sprung from the protests started with the goal of highlighting the disproportionate number of incidences in which a police officer killed a member of the black community. But it soon gained international recognition, after the death of Michael Brown in Missouri a year later.

Black Lives Matter now describes itself as a “chapter-based national organization working for the validity of black life”. It has developed to include the issues of black women and LGBT communities, undocumented black people and black people with disabilities.. 

Q: Has Black Lives Matter given any comments on alledged images with text attacking white people?
A: Yes. A spokesperson said: "It has recently come to our attention at the African Community Edinburgh, the organisers of the Black Lives Matter protest at Holyrood Park, that posters and flyers have been produced with the heading 'shoot whites on sight, silence is violence' claiming to be from Black Lives Matter. 

"We categorically deny that these were created on our behalf and we denounce such hate speech.

"We are not affiliated with Antifa, or any political party, as we are a grassroots network mobilised to bring attention to the plight of black people worldwide in order to end institutionalised racism, state sanctioned violence and anti-black and brown racism.

Q: Is there any reports of Black Lives Matter antagonising white people with racial attacks?
A: No answer could be found..

title: Fact Check: The first slaves shipped to the American colonies in 1619 were 100 white childre...
text:
Claim: The first slaves shipped to the American colonies in 1619 were 100 white children from Ireland.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification:  Between 1610 and 1619 no record of white children or white slaves being shipped to the American colonies appears in The Library of Congress records.

Evidence:

Q: What year did the first slave ships arrive in the American colonies?
A: As early as  1526, enslaved Africans were part of a Spanish expedition to establish an outpost on the North American coast in present-day South Carolina. 

Q: Were any white slaves recorded as being sent to American colonies around 1619?
A: No. between 1610 and 1619 no record of white children or white slaves being shipped to the American colonies appears in The Library of Congress records.

Q: What is the difference between slavery and servitude?
A: The most common form of forced labor in the history of civilization is slavery. Servitude is the general term used to describe all types of forced labor. It is derived from the Latin noun servus, which really means “slave,” though it is recognizable as the source of “servant” as well. Throughout the ancient world, anyone who functioned as a servant was usually a slave.

In the kind of servitude called slavery, the laborer is considered property. He or she can be bought and sold like any other commodity. The origins of slavery are unknown, but it probably emerged as an economic necessity or convenience when people began to establish permanent communities based on agriculture..

title: Fact Check: The law in Ireland in 1619 held that it was was no more a sin to kill an Irishma...

Q: Was it equally sinful to kill a dog as an Irishman in 1619
A: A law enacted in 1723 provided that for someone standing accused of manslaughter to be acquitted he
had only to show that the slain victim was Irish. Anglo- Norman priests granted absolution on the grounds
that it was ‘no more sin to kill an Irishman than a dog or any other brute’.. 

Q: Was it equally sinful to kill a dog as an Irishman in 1619?

title: Fact Check: 20% of African Americans had jobs where they could work from home during the Cov...
text:

Q: Did  COVID-19  Affected  Black/African Americans ?
A: Before the crisis hit, many Black and Latino workers held jobs done outside the home. Only 35.4 percent of Black adults and 25.2 percent of Latino adults reported they can do part of their work remotely, compared with 43.4 percent of white adults. Though reporting somewhat higher averages, these estimates largely correspond with earlier US Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data on racial and ethnic differences in the ability to work from home.

Differences in who can telework could indicate who’s at higher risk of losing a job, hours, or income. But despite multiple sources showing Black and Latino adults are less able to work from home compared with white adults, families of nonelderly Black adults experienced only minimally higher rates of job loss.

Black workers in particular are disproportionately employed in many of the jobs considered “essential,” suggesting Black workers may experience less drastic job losses than would be expected.
Table: risky jobs.

title: Fact Check: Vitamin D helps protect against COVID-19.
text:
Claim: Vitamin D helps protect against COVID-19.

Verdict: Not Enough Evidence

Justification: the question/answer pairs show that while vitamin D can help the immune system, there is no evidence that it prevents covid-19

Evidence:

Q: How can Vitamin D help reduce COVID-19?
A: Vitamin D may strengthen the immune system, particularly of people whose Vitamin D levels are low. 

Q: Is there evidence to suggest that vitamin D could prevent or treat COVID-19?
A: We found no clinical evidence on vitamin D in COVID-19. There was no evidence related to vitamin D deficiency predisposing to COVID-19, nor were there studies of supplementation for preventing or treating COVID-19.. 

Q: Could vitamin D help decrease the chance of covid 19?
A: “There are many crackpot claims about miracle cures floating around,” he wrote, “but the science supports the possibility – although not the proof – that Vitamin D may strengthen the immune system, particularly of people whose Vitamin D levels are low.”.

title: Fact Check: Assam Government Announces, "100% free admission for students in colleges up to ...
text:
Claim: Assam Government Announces, "100% free admission for students in colleges up to the postgraduate level.  "No colleges are allowed to charge any student for anything. No Saraswati Puja charges, no excursion fees, no prospectus fees. If any colleges are found charging students for anything during the admission, strict actions will be taken against them,"

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The answers show that the claim is true as there will be no fees for admissions during the covid pandemic.

Evidence:

Q: What did the Assam government decide regarding educational admission fees at the time of the claim?
A: Admission to universities, colleges and higher secondary schools in Assam will be free during the current academic year to ensure there is no additional burden on parents already affected by the coronavirus lockdown, Education Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma said on Sunday. He said there will be no hidden costs.

“Students from the higher secondary to the postgraduate level, including medical, engineering and polytechnic students, will be admitted to institutes for free,” Sarma told reporters, a day after results for Class 10 state board examinations were announced only on online platforms.

The prospectus and admission forms will be free and available online.. 

Q: What did the Education Minister Himanta Biswa Sarma publish on his twitter account regarding this claim?
A: #AssamEduCare Extremely pleased to share GOA has made ALL admissions - from HS upto PG level including medical, engineering, polytechnic for academic year 2020-21 - absolutely free. Under stress due to #COVID19, this shall be big relief to families. All prospectus will be free.. 

Q: What was the The Education Minister of Assam, Himanta Biswa Sarma quoted as saying on June 7, 2020 in the Barack Bulletin.
A: "No colleges are allowed to charge any student for anything. No Saraswati Puja charges, no excursion fees, no prospectus fees. If any colleges are found charging students for anything during the admission, strict actions will be taken against them," informed Sarma..

title: Fact Check: Democratic assembly woman for the 143rd District of New York. Monica Wallace Sig...

A: Drug overdose deaths were 62,172 in 2019. 

Q: How many drug overdose deaths were reported in the U.S. in 2018?

title: Fact Check: The Federal Police did not use chemical irritants to clear the area around St. J...
text:

Evidence:

Q: Did the Federal Police use chemical irritants to clear the area by DC church?
A: Yes. They used pepper balls.

Q: How is a pepper ball used by the Police?
A: A pepper ball is typically a projectile filled with pepper spray, usually launched from a device similar to a pistol. Police often carry them on their utility belts. According to a company that manufactures pepper balls, they are designed to create a 12-foot cloud with an irritant designed to affect the eyes, nose and throat of the people who are hit by the cloud.. 

Q: What does a pepper ball contain?
A: ...highly irritating
pepper powder..

title: Fact Check: The first Prime Minister of India, Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru gave an interview to Pla...
text:
Claim: The first Prime Minister of India, Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru gave an interview to Playboy magazine and the article was published in 1963.

Verdict: Conflicting Evidence/Cherrypicking

Justification: From the evidence given, it looks as though India's Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru has had connections with Playboy magazine regarding an interview. However, there were disputes over whether an interview even took place in the first place. There has been no investigation to determine the truth. Hence, this is conflicting evidence. 

Evidence:

Q: According to Forbes magazine, who has had interviews published in Playboy?
A: ...landing interviews with some of the world’s most prominent figures, including Malcom X, Fidel Castro, The Beatles, Martin Luther King Jr., Jimmy Hoffa, George Wallace, Henry Miller and Cassisus Clay. This was just in the first three years. The magazine would go on to interview President Jimmy Carter, among many others.. 

Q: Was Jawaharlal Nehru, India’s first prime minister included in the list of interviewees?
A: But many will be surprised to learn that the first head-of-state to appear in Playboy’s controversial pages was not Castro or Carter, but Jawaharlal Nehru, India’s first prime minister and most prominent founding father alongside Mahatma Gandhi.. 

Q: What was the subsequent retraction in the same issue of Playboy about this interview?
A: The same issue of the magazine carried an “editor’s note” on Page 3, which stated, “after the rest of the magazine had gone to press, we received word from the Indian Embassy in Washington that our interview with PM Nehru was not, in fact, the result of an exclusive, personal conversation with the head of the Indian state, but simply a gathering together of public pronouncements made by the Prime Minister in various speeches, statements, etc., over the past several years.”.

title: Fact Check: Wastewater can be an early indicator for a coronavirus outbreak.
text:
Claim: Wastewater can be an early indicator for a coronavirus outbreak.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: Confirmed via research in multiple countries.

Evidence:

Q: Are the authorities testing water as part of their campaign to detect Covid levels?
A: Hundreds of U.S. utilities are now running such tests as part of studies, and the current decline in cases will give public health systems time to get effective wastewater surveillance programs in place. After all, Finland is testing water in 28 sites every week, the Netherlands in 37, and Germany in 20 per day, said microbiologist Gertjan Medema of KWR, a water research institute in the Netherlands. Wastewater surveillance can provide “an early warning tool to see if cases are rising again,” he said.. 

Q: Has research been done in other countries ?
A: Research in the Netherlands, France, Australia and elsewhere has found signs that the virus that causes COVID-19 can be detected in sewage, and many countries are beginning to sample wastewater to track the disease..

title: Fact Check: Video in India shows that Putting basil leaves, camphor inside masks will purify...
text:
Claim: Video in India shows that Putting basil leaves, camphor inside masks will purify the air and will protect you from Covid-19

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: No evidence shows that basil leaves and camphor will protect you from Covid-19.

Evidence:

Q: Does camphor have any health benefits?
A: Camphor is highly toxic. While it is readily absorbed from the skin most toxic exposure is from ingestion
Common substances containing camphor include:
Vicks inhaler
Rubs including Dencorub, Tiger balm, Emu oils, Vicks VapoRub
Mothballs (some mothballs instead contain naphthalene or paradichlorobenzene)
The Victorian Poisons Information Centre does not recommend the use of camphor, as it has no proven health benefits, and is unsafe in houses (refer to info sheet in discharge section).. 

Q: Does basil have any health benefits?
A: People use holy basil for anxiety, stress, diabetes, high cholesterol, and many other conditions, but there is no good scientific evidence to support any of these uses..

title: Fact Check: Joe Biden stated in a debate from July 2019 that fossil fuels including coal and...
text:
Claim: Joe Biden stated in a debate from July 2019 that fossil fuels including coal and fracking would be eliminated in a Biden administration.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The question answer pairs show that Joe Biden wouldn't ban fracking and would encourage a movement towards sustainable energy sources but there is no evidence that fossil fuels and fracking would be eliminated in a Biden administration.

Evidence:

Q: What does the Biden administration say about fossil fuels?
A: His campaign issued a statement saying, “Joe Biden is committed to achieving a 100% clean energy economy and net-zero emissions by 2050. He supports eliminating subsidies for coal and gas and deploying carbon capture sequestration technology to create economic benefits for multiple industries and significantly reduce carbon dioxide emissions.”. 

Q: Does Biden's statement mean fossil fuels will be eliminated during the Biden administration?
A: No. The plan is a long term plan to encourage the movement away from fossil fuels and towards more sustainable energy sources. "he will demand that Congress enacts legislation in the first year of his presidency that: 1) establishes an enforcement mechanism that includes milestone targets no later than the end of his first term in 2025, 2) makes a historic investment in clean energy and climate research and innovation, 3) incentivizes the rapid deployment of clean energy innovations across the economy, especially in communities most impacted by climate change."

Q: Does the Biden campaign say anything specifically about fracking?
A: A spokesman for Mr. Biden’s campaign clarified that the former vice president wouldn’t ban fracking, which is now commonly used to produce natural gas and oil in key states with blue-collar voters like Pennsylvania, Ohio and Colorado. He was referring only to his stated policy to ban new permits for oil and gas drilling on federal land and offshore, the spokesman added..

In that capacity, he served as the vice chairman and a permanent member of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), the group responsible for formulating the nation's monetary policy..

title: Fact Check: The COVID-19 pandemic has helped bolster the relationship between China and Midd...
text:
Claim: The COVID-19 pandemic has helped bolster the relationship between China and Middle Eastern countries.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: It does seem that the relationships have improved due to the covid-19 pandemic.

Evidence:

Q: What effect has the Covid-19 Pandemic had on China - Middle East relations?
A: The surprising effect of the COVID-19 pandemic has been to foster comradeship between China and most Middle-Eastern states in combatting a common enemy. 

Q: How have China & Middle eastern countries helped each other during the pandemic?
A: Iran Projected China’s national flag and words of support on to its famous Azadi Tower.

title: Fact Check: Bird e-scooters are shutting down service in the Middle East, and scrapping as m...
text:
Claim: Bird e-scooters are shutting down service in the Middle East, and scrapping as many as 10,000 scooters.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The sources show that the company are scrapping 10,000 scooters as they are not able to be resold due to their bad condition. Therefore the claim is supported.

Evidence:

Q: How many bird e-scooters were in circulation  in the Middle East, at the time of this claim.
A: Circ acquired bird in january 2020. there are approximately 8,000-1000 Circ e-scooters in circulation between Qatar, Bahrain, and the United Arab Emirates.. 

Q: Are circ shitting down any services in any cities?
A: Circ, the E-scooter company that acquired Bird back in January, has announced that they are shutting down their service in several cities in the Middle East as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Currently, there are approximately 8,000-1000 Circ e-scooters in circulation between Qatar, Bahrain, and the United Arab Emirates. According to a former Circ employee who asked to remain anonymous, Bird is paying $300,000 to have the e-scooters removed from the region.. 

Q: Are they being scrapping the scooters?
A: Following extreme wear and tear, the Circ vehicles no longer met our rigorous quality standards,” said a spokesperson for the company. “Selling or re-use of these vehicles would potentially result in safety and reliability issues, which would not have been fair or ethical to the purchasers or potential riders. We look forward to resuming our service throughout more parts of the region later this year.” as many as 10,000 Circ scooters have been sent to a third-party UAE-based company for recycling, as a result of the supposed “pause in operations”..

title: Fact Check: Over 600 elephants are killed in Kerala every year.
text:
Claim: Over 600 elephants are killed in Kerala every year.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: the total for 5 years is less than the amount stated in the claim which relates to 1 year.

Evidence:

Q: What is the main cause of death for elephants in India?
A: Electrocution.. 

Q: How many elephants have died in total in India, in the years 2015-2019?
A: data from 2015-2019 (up to 31 December 2018) shows that there have been a total of 373 elephant deaths in total across India.. 

Q: How many elephant deaths were in Kerala alone in the same time period?
A: for the period between 2015-2019, Kerala reported 39 elephant deaths due to various reasons including train accidents, poaching, and electrocution..

title: Fact Check: The Supreme Court of India has ruled in favour of renaming the country in all la...
text:
Claim: The Supreme Court of India has ruled in favour of renaming the country in all languages.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The Q&A state that the supreme court did not rule in favour or against renaming the country in all languages. but it does point out that court sent it to be considered only.

Evidence:

Q: What was the  Supreme Court of India's Ruling regarding renaming the country in all languages.?
A: The bench refused to interfere but send the petition as a representation to the Centre for its consideration.

title: Fact Check: “India let 65 lakh tonne of grain go waste in four months, even as the poor went...
text:
Claim: “India let 65 lakh tonne of grain go waste in four months, even as the poor went hungry.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Although some food was wasted due to floods whilst on transit, it was a gross misinterpretation 

Evidence:

Q: Which Government body is responsible for distribution of food in India?
A: Food Corporation of India. 

Q: What was their response to the claim?
A: Misleading news published in 
@scroll_in
 on Food Grains gone waste, FCI's rebuttal attached. 

Q: Did FCI add to their tweet?
A: Yes. They added a letter.

title: Fact Check: Hillary Clinton is on trial for the 2002 terror attack on Americans in Benghazi,...
text:
Claim: Hillary Clinton is on trial for the 2002 terror attack on Americans in Benghazi, Libya.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The first answer shows that Clinton was not on trial but was involved in the case so the claim is refuted.

Evidence:

Q: Was Hillary Clinton put on trial for the 2002 terror attack on Americans in Benghazi, Libya?
A: A court case involving Clinton was in court, but she wasn’t on trial.. 

Q: Did the United States setup a House Committee to question Hillary Clinton over  2002 terror attack on Americans in Benghazi, Libya?
A: Democratic presidential candidate and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton spent 11 hours answering questions from the House Benghazi Committee Thursday. At one point, the hearing devolved into a yelling match between Committee Chairman Trey Gowdy and Democrats on the committee.

The bickering followed Gowdy's questions regarding Clinton's email correspondence with Sidney Blumenthal, a longtime Clinton family friend and informal adviser. Democrats on the committee suggested Gowdy's line of questioning was unfair and politically motivated.

"If you think we've heard about Sidney Blumenthal, wait for the next round!" Gowdy declared before abruptly calling a recess in the middle of the marathon hearing.

Gowdy questioned why Clinton exchanged so many emails with Blumenthal pertaining to Libya, even though Blumenthal "could not get hired by our government... had never been to Libya, [and] had no expertise with Libya."

    Hillary Clinton's Benghazi testimony: A viewer's guide
    What Hillary Clinton will say before the Benghazi panel

Gowdy suggested it was suspicious that Blumenthal, "all the while working with the Clinton Foundation and some pseudo-news entities, had unfettered access to you." By contrast, Gowdy said that Clinton's records showed "not a single email to and from Ambassador [Chris] Stevens," the administration's trusted man on the ground in Libya and one of the four Americans killed in the September 11, 2012 attack on a U.S. facility in Benghazi.. 

Q: What did Hillary Clinton say about  the 2002 terror attack on Americans in Benghazi, Libya ?
A: The moment Hillary Clinton seemed to realize that her testimony Thursday before the House Select Committee on Benghazi was not going to be a big problem for her or for her campaign came about forty-five minutes in. When the hearing opened, she had regarded the chairman, Trey Gowdy, of South Carolina, with irritated skepticism. She looked as if she might say something rash, if not throw something, and perhaps she might have. Nearly three years ago, in a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Benghazi, she lashed out after having been asked many times about U.N. Ambassador Susan Rice’s comments on the Sunday talk shows about what had instigated the attack, on September 11, 2012, in which four Americans, including Chris Stevens, the Ambassador to Libya, died. “What difference, at this point, does it make?” Clinton demanded. Out of context, she sounded unmoved by the men’s deaths. Now, in the House hearing, it seemed to dawn on her that the proper response to her Republican interrogators was not outrage but pity.

Peter Roskam, of Illinois, was laying out a scenario in which Clinton’s assumption of a leadership role on Libyan policy “didn’t come easy,” when he stopped and said, in case he might be overwhelming her, “I can pause while you’re reading your notes from your staff.” Clinton replied, “I can do more than one thing at a time, Congressman—thanks.” A minute or two later, Roskam said, “Go ahead and read the note if you need to.” This time, Clinton laughed. “I’m not done with my question,” Roskam said; he was just doing her a “courtesy.” “That’s all right,” Clinton responded, with a friendly wave of her hand. From then on, she was in control. “I’m sorry that doesn’t fit your narrative, Congressman. I can only tell you what the facts are,” she told Jim Jordan, of Ohio, who is the chairman of the Freedom Caucus. As he spoke, she rested her chin on the palm of one hand, as if he were not much more than a loud boor at a party who, puzzlingly, doesn’t seem to kn.

title: Fact Check: The COVID-19 tests conducted at the 199 testing centres in the UK, as well as th...
text:
Claim: The COVID-19 tests conducted at the 199 testing centres in the UK, as well as the mobile test centres, are all done within 24 hours.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Not all tests were given results within 24 hours. However the claim is badly worded as it could be read as all test conducted where carried out within 24 hours. So the meaning is ambiguous. 

Evidence:

Q: how many tests were done in the uk in 24 hours?
A: When this was said, on 3 June, 19% of tests at regional testing sites and 5% of tests at mobile test centres were done within 24 hours.. 

Q: How long does it take for a COVID-19 test result carried out in the UK mobile test centers take to be released
A: 96.7% of tests results were received the next day after the test was taken. 95.8% of test results were received within 48 hours of booking a test.

title: Fact Check: Zimbabwe's fuel consumption is the same as Ethiopia's.
text:
Claim: Zimbabwe's fuel consumption is the same as Ethiopia's.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Q&A 3 shows that Zimbabwe used about 1.5 billion litres a year whilst Q&A 4 shows Ethiopia's  as 4.5 billion litres a year which contradicts the claim Ethiopia's is the same as Zimbabwe's 

Evidence:

Q: What is Zimbabwe's fuel consumption?
A: Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe governor John Mangudya said Zimbabwe uses 1.5 billion litres of fuel in a year.
(June 2020). 

Q: What is Ethiopia's fuel consumption?
A: 2017/18 3,501,759 MT. 

Q: How much fuel does Zimbabwe consume in a year
A: A video shows the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe governor saying  that they consume about 1.5 billion litres of fuel in a year.

title: Fact Check: Ultraviolet light could kill the coronavirus (SARS-CoV2)
text:
Claim: Ultraviolet light could kill the coronavirus (SARS-CoV2)

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The questions and answers come to the conclusion that far-UVC light can kill viruses and bacteria and coronavirus is classed as a family of viruses, so it might be possible, the claim seems to be supported.

Evidence:

Q: What Is COVID-19?
A: COVID-19 is a new strain of coronavirus. 

Q: What is a coronavirus?
A: Term describes a family of viruses, common in both animals and humans. 

Q: What types of light can kill a virus?
A: far-UVC, which can kill viruses and bacteria without harming human skin, eyes and other tissues.

title: Fact Check: The Instagram algorithm is merging #BlackOutTuesday posts with the #BlackLivesMa...
text:
Claim: The Instagram algorithm is merging #BlackOutTuesday posts with the #BlackLivesMatter hashtag.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Q&A pairs explain it was a user created problem rather than an algorithm one at Instagram's end.

Evidence:

Q: What happened on Instagram on June 2 2020 with #blackouttuesday and #blacklivesmatter hashtags?
A: Instagram users flooded the platform with black squares in support of black victims of police violence as part of a Blackout Tuesday protest. As of 11:45 a.m. ET, more than 14.6 million Instagram posts used the hashtag #BlackoutTuesday.. 

Q: Why did users think that the Instagram algorithm was merging #BlackOutTuesday posts with the #BlackLivesMatter hashtag?
A: People used hashtags meant for Black Lives Matter, which usually is related to global protests and donations, on their black squares. That caused the usual #BLM and #BlackLivesMatter pages to be flooded with simple squares rather than information and resources, leading users to believe Instagram had merged their posts.. 

Q: What was Instagram's explanation for the users thinking that the #BLM and #BlackLivesMatter, and #BlackOutTuesday hashtags had been merged?
A: Instagram explained to USA TODAY that because the “Most Recent" section of the hashtag page shows posts reverse chronologically, a rush of new "Blackout Tuesday" posts can bury older #BlackLivesMatter and #BLM posts..

title: Fact Check: The tragic incident where a pregnant elephant died after allegedly being fed a p...
text:
Claim: The tragic incident where a pregnant elephant died after allegedly being fed a pineapple stuffed with firecrackers took place in Malappuram, a Muslim-dominated district in Kerala, India.

Verdict: Not Enough Evidence

Justification: The answer shows that there has not been a conclusion on the incident and so there is not enough evidence to support or refute the claim.

Evidence:

Q: Did a pregnant elephant die after being fed a pineapple stuffed with firecrackers in Malappuram, a Muslim-dominated district in Kerala, India?
A: The investigation of the elephant’s death is ongoing and the exact details of the incident are yet to be determined. However, the initial probe suggests that the wild animal was not directly fed a pineapple laden with firecrackers but she may have accidentally consumed it..

title: Fact Check: A German Shephard dog in New York state, USA was the first domesticated dog in t...
text:
Claim: A German Shephard dog in New York state, USA was the first domesticated dog in the United States to test positive for Covid-19 infection.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The second answer and source shows that a domesticated dog did test positive for covid and so the  claim is supported.

Evidence:

Q: Can animals catch COVID-19?
A: Yes. Recent reports of SARS-CoV-2 infecting creatures such as monkeys, dogs, ferrets, domestic cats and even a tiger have raised the possibility that the pathogen could plague other species—including, perhaps, ones already imperiled by other, non-infectious threats.

Q: Did a dog test positive for COVID-19?
A: Yes. The Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) National Veterinary Services Laboratories confirmed earlier this week that a case of COVID-19 has infected a German shepherd in New York.

The dog was tested after it displayed signs of a respiratory infection. Additionally, one of the dog’s owners had also tested positive for the disease, however, this was before the dog had shown signs of infection.

title: Fact Check: An elephant was 'fed' a pineapple laced with firecrackers and the incident took ...
text:
Claim: An elephant was 'fed' a pineapple laced with firecrackers and the incident took place in Kerala's Malappuram district.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: Confirmed via QA Pairs.

Evidence:

Q: Did An elephant die in Kerala's Malappuram district in 2020?
A: Yes. Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan tweeted , ...
''In a tragic incident in palakkad dist, a pregnant elephant has lost its life. and that justice will prevail.

Q: What were the circumstances surrounding the pregnant elephants death?
A: An elephant in a weak condition happened to die after somebody unlawfully used an explosive in food. It sustained the injury while trying to eat that food. 

Q: Do people in the region usually put explosives in food?
A: Yes. For snares, which are usually  fruits stuffed with explosives, that are commonly used as bait for wild boars either to kill them for meat or to stop them from destroying vegetation.

title: Fact Check: During the widespread unrest that has occurred in the United States after the mu...
text:
Claim: During the widespread unrest that has occurred in the United States after the murder of unarmed African American man George Floyd in Minneapolis, Minnesota on Memorial Day 2020, a video began circulating on social media. The video claims to show two white police officers attempting to arrest a Sudenese American FBI agent.

Verdict: Refuted

Evidence:

Q: What did the police department say about the claim that the man was an FBI agent
A: The police head said, "Contrary to social media rumors, the individual was not a Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI) agent.".

title: Fact Check: The NBA told president Trump to resign or they would never play again
text:

Q: Did the NBA threaten to “never play again” unless Trump resigns ?
A: No answer could be found..

title: Fact Check: A new executive order put in place by President Donald Trump to target social me...
text:
Claim: A new executive order put in place by President Donald Trump to target social media companies is in violation of the First Amendment and free speech protections.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: Evidence finds that President Donald Trump's new executive order, which would target social media companies, is a violation of the First Amendment and free speech protections.

Evidence:

Q: Was President Trump executive order on Social media companies a violation of the First Amendment and free speech protections ?
A: Rather than protecting free speech, undermining Section 230 in this way will restrict more speech online. It will make it easier for the government itself to exert the levers of censorship, fundamentally undermining First Amendment rights in the United States.”. 

Q: Was the Trump's Executive Order a threat to future online speech ?
A: ARTICLE 19 has condemned US President Donald Trump’s use of an Executive Order designed to force social media companies into moderating content as he sees fit. 

Executive Director Quinn McKew said:

“The use of an Executive Order to undermine key speech protections online threatens the internet as we know it.  

“For the President  to claim that he is doing this in the name of free speech is disingenuous at best.  Fact checking is not censorship, it is more speech. This is a clear attempt to push  companies into moderating content in line with the President’s interpretation of free speech, ahead of a divisive presidential election where social media will be a key campaigning battleground.”

The Executive Order seeks to undermine protections in Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. This shields online intermediaries from liability for what their users say and protects intermediaries’ ability to moderate content on their  platforms. Intermediaries include Internet Service Providers and social media platforms, such as Twitter, Facebook and YouTube. Platforms also have their own free speech rights and their editorial functions are protected under the First Amendment.

McKew added: “Rather than protecting free speech, undermining Section 230 in this way will restrict more speech online. It will make it easier for the government itself to exert the levers of censorship, fundamentally undermining First Amendment rights in the United States.”

The row between Twitter and the President looks set to intensify after the social media platform marked tweets which threatened the use of force in the wake of civil unrest in Minneapolis as in violation of rules about glorifying violence. This is the first time Twitter uses such a label against a head of state and the US President in particular. In line with Twitter policy, the tweet was not removed as Twitter said it might be in the public interest but the public interest notice “limits the ability to engage with the Tweet. 

Q: Can Social media companies be sued under Trump's Executive Order ?
A: The social media executive order makes it easier for companies like Twitter, Facebook and Google to be held liable for the content posted on their platforms, according to a draft obtained by ABC News..

title: Fact Check: South-South zonal head of Nigeria’s anti-graft agency, the Economic and Financia...
text:
Claim: South-South zonal head of Nigeria’s anti-graft agency, the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC), Ishaq Salihu, addressed a group of protesters in its Port-Harcourt office, Rivers state recently over the trial of George Turnah.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: this didn't happen recently, it is misrepresented and therefore false. 

Evidence:

Q: Did Youths storm EFCC’s South-South office in Port Harcourt, Rivers State on June 3rd 2020 as stated in the claim
A: No, this story was first published online on June 1st 2017.. 

Q: Was George Turnah having a trial to protest over?
A: His trial was in 2016 and he was never rearrested.. 

Q: was the evidence provided proven to be a correct happening
A: several Google searches revealed that the claim is at least three years old as the exact content of the report was first posted online on Nairaland.

title: Fact Check: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya said, ‘At independence, we had only 1,800 kilo...
text:
Claim: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya said, ‘At independence, we had only 1,800 kilometres of tarmacked roads.’

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The Q&A pair give a figure that is very close to the claim so it seems supportive.

Evidence:

Q: Did President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya said, ‘At independence, we had only 1,800 kilometres of tarmacked roads.’?
A: A 1968 World Bank document published in response to Kenya’s request for a loan to build a highway gives historical data from 1957 to 1966, citing a 1966 statistical abstract as its source. 
The document says Kenya had 1,112 miles of paved road at independence in 1963. We could not find the 1966 statistical abstract, but according to the 1967 edition, Kenya’s data agency recorded 1,112 miles of paved road in 1963..

title: Fact Check: US President Trump sent out a tweet claiming that he and Vice President Pence we...
text:
Claim: US President Trump sent out a tweet claiming that he and Vice President Pence were escorted to the secret White House bunker, and that former President Obama had left it dirty and unsupplied.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: there is no evidence that Trump sent this tweet

Evidence:

Q: What is the white house bunker?
A: The Presidential Emergency Operations Center (PEOC, PEE-ock) is a bunker-like structure underneath the East Wing of the White House. It serves as a secure shelter and communications center for the president of the United States and others in case of an emergency. Washington, D.C.. 

Q: Did Donald Trump tweet that the bunker was in very bad shape, dirty and with no food or supplies?
A: No. There is no mention of food or supplies on Donald Trumps twitter.

title: Fact Check: At independence from British Rule in 1963, Kenya had only 1,800 kilometres of ta...
text:
Claim: At independence from British Rule in 1963, Kenya had only 1,800 kilometres of tarmacked roads.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: The answer and credible source show that the claim has the correct amount of road so the claim is supported.

Evidence:

Q: At independence, how many tarmacked roads did Kenya have?
A: 1, 800 km. of paved roads at the time of independence.

title: Fact Check: Wearing a mask for an extended time may lead to death.
text:
Claim: Wearing a mask for an extended time may lead to death.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: From the question and answer pair it seems that no one ever died from wearing a face mask. Therefore, the claim is refuted.

Evidence:

Q: Has anyone died from wearing a surgical mask
A: Nobody has ever died as a direct result of wearing a surgical mask says Ryan Marino, an emergency medicine physician at University Hospital Cleveland Medical Center.

title: Fact Check: Gretchen Whitmer, the governor of Michigan is the niece of George Soros.
text:
Claim: Gretchen Whitmer, the governor of Michigan is the niece of George Soros.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: George Soros has no surviving nieces or nephews 

Evidence:

Q: is Gretchen Whitmer related to George Soros.?
A: Soros’ brother, Paul Soros, died in 2013. According to his obituary in the New York Times, he was survived by two sons: Peter and Jeffrey. He had two other children but they both died at 18 months old. A third son, Steven, was in a playground accident and a daughter, Linda, was hit by a vehicle backing out of the family’s garage.

So George Soros has no surviving nieces. And his nephews didn’t marry Whitmer (whose husband is Marc Mallory, a dentist in Lansing, Mich.)..

title: Fact Check: On Kenyas independence, they only had 1,800 kilometres of tarmacked roads
text:
Claim: On Kenyas independence, they only had 1,800 kilometres of tarmacked roads

Verdict: Supported

Justification: True, but didnt require so many Q/A, just one

Evidence:

Q: When did Kenya declare independence?
A: Kenya became independent from British colonial rule on 12 December 1963.. 

Q: Who has data on Kenya's road network?
A: Kenya's national statistics bureau. 

Q: What figure does the national statistics bureau give for how many Kilometres of roads Kenya had at independence?
A: The bureau’s economic survey for 1983 notes a growth in the road network “from 1,800 kilometres of paved roads at the time of independence”..

title: Fact Check: Kenya's president claims ' from 2013, and in only 7 years of my presidency, we h...
text:
Claim: Kenya's president claims ' from 2013, and in only 7 years of my presidency, we have connected close to 3.5 million households to electricity, bringing the number of households connected close to 8 million.”

Verdict: Not Enough Evidence

Justification: QA pairs imply between 6 million and 7.5 million Kenyan households were connected to electricity which is less than the 8 million claimed.
Missing evidence: evidence that 3.5 million Kenyan households were connected to electricity during 7 years of the presidency.
Additionally two of the source links for the first and second QA pairs are to error pages on the fact checking website Africa Check (i.e. not independent evidence sources).

Evidence:

Q: How many households are there in Kenya?
A: 12.1 million. 

Q: How many households in Kenya are connected to electricty?
A: Slightly
over half (50.4 per cent) of households reported using electricity mains as a source of
lighting fuel. 

Q: How many Kenyan households were connected to electricity in 2013?
A: No answer could be found..

title: Fact Check: Democratic Michigan governor Gretchen Whitmer is the niece of billionaire invest...
text:
Claim: Democratic Michigan governor Gretchen Whitmer is the niece of billionaire investor George Soros.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: she is not his niece.

Evidence:

Q: does billionaire investor George Soros have any brothers or sisters?
A: George Soros had one brother, Paul Soros. Paul died in 2013 and was survived by two sons, Two of his other children died in infancy in tragic accidents. 

Q: Did Gretchen Whitmer marry either of George Soros’s nephews?
A: Gretchen Whitmer did not marry either of George Soros’s nephews. Her first husband was Gary Shrewsbury. The couple divorced and in 2011, Whitmer married Marc Mallory, a Lansing, Michigan native.

title: Fact Check: By June 2020, less than 100 people in Ireland had died directly from Covid-19.
text:
Claim: By June 2020, less than 100 people in Ireland had died directly from Covid-19.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: Almost 50 times more deaths in QA pair compared to claim.

Evidence:

Q: Before June 2020, how many confirmed COVID-19 deaths have been documented
A: By 13th May 2020, the total number of deaths was 4, 937.

title: Fact Check: After independence from British rule, Kenya's Founding Fathers, President Jomo K...
text:
Claim: After independence from British rule, Kenya's Founding Fathers, President Jomo Kenyatta, President Moi and President Kibaki, built 11,200 kilometres of tarmacked roads, in 50 years at an average of 224 kilometres per year.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: This claim is refuted. According to the QA pairs, Kenya built 9,441 kilometres over 50 years since British rule- not 11,200km. Therefore, this claim is refuted. 

Evidence:

Q: Did Kenya build 11,200 kilometres of tarmacked roads, in the 50 years post independence?
A: The independent Republic of Kenya was formed in 1963. 

Q: how many kilometres of paved roads had Kenya built between 1963 and 2013?
A: there were 2,541 kilometres  of roads built between 1968 and 1978
an average of about 170 kilometres a year. 

Q: How many kilometres of paved roads had Kenya built between 1963 and 2013?
A: 2,293 kilometres built between 2003 and 2013
229 kilometres built per year.

title: Fact Check: The United States of America will be designating ANTIFA as a domestic Terrorist ...
text:
Claim: The United States of America will be designating ANTIFA as a domestic Terrorist Organization.

Verdict: Supported

Justification: Correct claim

Evidence:

Q: Is there a current legal authority in the U.S. for designating a domestic organization as a terrorist organization?
A: No. “No current legal authority exists for designating domestic organizations as terrorist organizations. Any attempt at such a designation would raise significant First Amendment concerns.”

@GeorgetownICAP’s Mary McCord

Q: Have concerns been raised about designating a domestic organization as a terrorist organization?
A: Yes. "designation of a domestic organization as a terrorist organization would raise serious concerns about infringing on First Amendment rights and cause legitimate fears that the designation tool could be used wrongly to target unpopular ideologies". written by Mary B. McCord and Jason M. Blazakis , director of the Middlebury Institute of International Studies’ Center on Terrorism, Extremism, and Counterterrorism.

Q: What is the Antifa Organization?
A: Antifa is short for anti-fascists. The term is used to define a broad group of people whose political beliefs lean toward the left – often the far left – but do not conform with the Democratic Party platform. The group doesn’t have an official leader or headquarters, although groups in certain states hold regular meetings.

Antifa positions can be hard to define, but many members support oppressed populations and protest the amassing of wealth by corporations and elites. Some employ radical or militant tactics to get their message across..

title: Fact Check: Kenya's president claims 'After 78 years of colonial rule and 50 years of the in...
text:
Claim: Kenya's president claims 'After 78 years of colonial rule and 50 years of the independence administrations, a total of 4.5 million households were connected to electricity'.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The figure in the claim  is higher than the figures in the answers.  

Evidence:

Q: How many domestic households are connected to electricity in Kenya?
A: In June 2013 the country had 2.1 million domestic households connected.. 

Q: When did kenya achive self rule?
A: The country achieved self-rule in June 1963. 

Q: What date was 50 years after 1963?
A: Fifty years after this was June 2013.

title: Fact Check: Ear loop face masks don't protect against Covid-19.
text:
Claim: Ear loop face masks don't protect against Covid-19.

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: they may not full protect but they offer some protection.

Evidence:

Q: How do masks help with the spread of Covid-19?
A: A well-fitting mask keeps the virus from reaching others. It can also protect the wearer from becoming infected. Also, masks stop people from touching their mouths and faces.. 

Q: Is there any benefit to wearing an ear loop face mask to help prevent catching or spreading covid 19?
A: Yes while they might not prevent you from catching the virus they assist in stopping the spread by catching the majority of droplets.


From Source page:

"cloth masks are also effective at reducing the spread of these smaller particles"

"We can see directly that a piece of cloth blocks those droplets and the virus those droplets contain. People without symptoms who don’t even know they are sick are responsible for around half of the transmission of the virus."

"This means that nearly any kind of simple cloth mask is great for source control. The mask creates humidity, this humidity prevents virus-containing droplets from turning into droplet nuclei, and this allows the fabric of the mask to block the droplets.".

title: Fact Check: After Kenya's independence, Kenyas Founding Fathers built an extra 11,200 kilome...
text:
Claim: After Kenya's independence, Kenyas Founding Fathers built an extra 11,200 kilometres of tarmacked roads. This was done in a period of 50 years by President Jomo Kenyatta, President Moi and President Kibaki, at an average of 224 kilometres per year.’

A: Kenyatta claimed is was 11200 kilometres but this includes roads built before independence..

title: Fact Check: Kenya's president said ' we have connected 99% of all schools to electricty'
text:
Claim: Kenya's president said ' we have connected 99% of all schools to electricty'

Verdict: Refuted

Justification: The figure would have been accurate if it is just referring to public primary schools and does not include Pre-primary and Secondary schools.

Evidence:

Q: Who electrifies schools in Kenya?
A: This is a shared responsibility between the Rural Electrification and Renewable Energy Corporation and state utility Kenya Power, according to energy ministry spokesperson Moses Nyandika.. 

Q: how many were electrified by 2016?
A: Before 2013, the rural electrification agency focused on secondary schools, according to its 2016-2021 strategic plan. Some 6,530 of these had been electrified by June 2013, when Kenyatta’s administration started its first full financial year.
The agency then turned its focus to primary schools to support the new government’s digital learning plan. By June 2016 it had connected 8,259 secondary schools, and 22,648 of 23,401 public primary schools targeted, according to the strategic plan.. 

Q: How many were connected as of 2020?
A: A spokesperson for the agency told Africa Check it has connected 22,927 public primary schools. This was 98.4% of the total number of public primary schools as of 2019.

The agency also told Africa Check some 8,755 public secondary schools, polytechnics and institutions of higher learning were connected as of 2020. But it did not break down this data further to allow us to calculate what percentage of secondary schools have been electrified.For early childhood development and education centres, some 204 have been provided with electricity, the agency said. This is less than 1%, or 0.7% specifically, of the 28,383 early childhood centres captured by the national statistics office for 2020.

The president’s figure would therefore have been accurate if he were referring only to public primary schools. Before his administration, some 6,530 secondary schools had already been connected, so he cannot take credit for them.

Available data also shows at least 99% of early childhood centres are not yet connected to electricity..

title: Fact Check: Vaccines will hook everyone up to an artificial intelligence interface
text:

Evidence:

Q: Is there technology in vaccines to hook us up to AIs
A: Vaccines work by mimicking an infectious agent, and by doing so, train our bodies to respond more rapidly and effectively against them. 

Q: Are there any microchips in vaccines?
A: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation told the BBC the claim was "false".. 

Q: Do any vaccines contain technology to link people up to an artificial intelligence interface?
A: they do not contain technology to link people up to an artificial intelligence interface..
